2. Presenting Problem
I have a persistent belief that if I can't find seasoned oak, all the furniture I build will look terrible, causing feelings of anxiety and self-doubt.

The problem has progressed to the point where I avoid building furniture altogether if I cannot find seasoned oak, affecting my hobby and self-esteem.
I experience this belief whenever I think about starting a new furniture project.
I have tried searching for alternative wood types and distractions, but the belief continues to plague me.

3. Reason for Seeking Counseling
The constant anxiety and self-doubt affecting my hobby and daily life made me realize the need to seek counseling for support and guidance.

4. Past History (including medical history)
I have not experienced similar problems before the traumatic robbery incident.
I have not received treatment or counseling for psychological problems in the past.
I do not have any significant physical illnesses.

5. Academic/occupational functioning level: My performance in house cleaning has been satisfactory despite the anxiety related to building furniture.
Interpersonal relationships: My relationships with friends have been strained as I often express my self-doubt and anxiety about furniture building.
Daily life: My anxiety has affected my ability to focus and enjoy hobbies like building furniture.

6. Social Support System
I have a good relationship with my father, who is a retired police officer, but I have not shared my feelings of anxiety and self-doubt with him.

2. Presenting Problem
I tend to discount the positive aspects of my life and often engage in black-and-white or all-or-nothing thinking. For example, if I miss out on one day of surfing due to weather, I label the entire month as ruined.
These cognitive distortions have been present for as long as I can remember but have become more pronounced in the past few months.
I believe the stress of balancing work at the bar, my surfing hobby, and trying to excel in my various skills has contributed to this negative thinking.
The problem has escalated recently, and I find myself feeling extremely disappointed and demotivated over minor setbacks.
I experience these thought patterns regularly, especially after perceived failures or setbacks.
I have attempted to challenge these thoughts with positive affirmations, but they don't seem to help much.

3. Reason for Seeking Counseling
I decided to seek counseling because these negative thinking patterns are significantly impacting my daily life and affecting my overall mood and motivation.

4. Past History (including medical history)
I have not experienced similar cognitive distortions before.
I have not received treatment or counseling for psychological problems in the past.
I do not have any significant physical illnesses.

5. Occupational Functioning Level: My work at the bar has not been affected, but my mood swings due to negative thinking.
Interpersonal relationships: My relationships with friends have been strained due to my constant pessimism.
Daily life: My negative thinking impacts my daily routine, including surfing and practicing the piano.

6. Social Support System
I have friends and colleagues I can talk to, but I have not discussed my cognitive distortions with them.

2. Presenting Problem
I have been feeling a sense of loneliness and isolation, especially thinking that no one will attend my funeral due to being an only child.

The stress level increased when I had to undergo a medical procedure alone, without any family to rely on.
These feelings have worsened over time, especially after a recent incident where I had to make a difficult decision on my own.
I experience these thoughts and feelings mostly at night before going to bed, and they keep me awake.
I have tried distracting myself with hobbies and reaching out to friends, but the feelings persist.

3. Reason for Seeking Counseling
The realization that these feelings of loneliness and thoughts about my funeral attendance are affecting my mental health and daily functioning prompted me to seek counseling.

4. Past History (including medical history)
I have not experienced similar problems before.
I have not received treatment or counseling for psychological problems in the past.
I do not have any significant physical illnesses.

5. Academic/occupational functioning level: My job performance has been impacted recently due to lack of focus and preoccupation with these thoughts.
Interpersonal relationships: My relationships with friends have been strained due to my withdrawal and inability to open up about my feelings.
Daily life: My sleep patterns have been disrupted, and I struggle with feelings of sadness and emptiness regularly.

6. Social Support System
I have a few close friends I can talk to, but I find it challenging to discuss these deep-seated feelings of loneliness with them.

2. Presenting Problem
I have a persistent belief that being an orphan who was in the foster care system makes me unlovable and horrible in the eyes of others. This belief has caused feelings of worthlessness and social isolation.
These feelings have been present since my early teenage years but have become more pronounced in the past year.
I believe the cause of these feelings stems from the experiences I had in the foster care system and the labels society places on orphans.
The problem has progressed to the point where I avoid social interactions and struggle to form meaningful connections with others.
I experience these feelings on a daily basis, especially when I meet new people or attempt to form relationships.
I have attempted to combat these feelings through self-help books and engaging in hobbies, but the thoughts persist.

3. Reason for Seeking Counseling
The worsening of these feelings of worthlessness and the impact on my social interactions and mental well-being have led me to seek counseling at this time.

4. Past History (including medical history)
I have experienced similar feelings of worthlessness and social isolation in the past, especially during my teenage years. I coped with these feelings by isolating myself further.
I have not received treatment or counseling for psychological problems in the past, nor do I have any significant physical illnesses.

5. Academic/occupational functioning level: My job performance in the navy has been affected due to the social isolation and feelings of worthlessness.
Interpersonal relationships: I struggle to form and maintain relationships due to my belief that I am unlovable.
Daily life: My feelings of worthlessness have impacted my daily life, including sleep patterns and self-care routines.

6. Social Support System
I do not have a strong social support system. I have some colleagues in the navy whom I interact with, but I struggle to open up about my feelings with them.

2. Presenting Problem
I have a persistent belief that people must think I am too fat because I never wear a swimsuit. This belief has led to feelings of self-consciousness and discomfort.
These feelings started during my teenage years and have become more pronounced in recent years.
I believe the cause of this issue stems from past experiences of judgment regarding my body.
The problem has escalated, especially during social gatherings or when the topic of swimming or beach trips arises. I tend to avoid such situations due to my insecurities.
I often find myself mind-reading and assuming what others must be thinking about me.
I have tried to overcome this by ordering swimsuits online in an attempt to feel more comfortable, but the underlying belief persists.

3. Reason for Seeking Counseling
I decided to seek counseling because these negative self-perceptions are affecting my social life and causing distress.

4. Past History (including medical history)
I have experienced similar body image issues before, especially during my teenage years.
I have not received specific treatment or counseling for these issues in the past.
I do not have any significant physical illnesses.

5. Academic/occupational functioning level: Not specified
Interpersonal relationships: My discomfort with my body has impacted my relationships with friends and romantic partners.
Daily life: Avoiding situations where I need to wear a swimsuit has limited my social interactions and activities.

6. Social Support System
I have a few close friends I can talk to, but I have not discussed these body image concerns with them.

2. Presenting Problem
I constantly feel overwhelmed by work and have a persistent fear that I will never be able to relax or enjoy life. This feeling of being overworked and the fear of dying on the job started a few years ago when the business started booming.
I believe the cause of this problem is the immense pressure to succeed and provide for my family.
The problem has worsened as the business expanded, and the workload increased. I find myself working long hours and neglecting self-care.
I experience these feelings daily, especially during busy workdays and when thinking about the future.
I have tried to delegate tasks and take short breaks, but I still struggle to find a work-life balance.

3. Reason for Seeking Counseling
I realized that this constant fear and feeling of being overworked were affecting my mental and physical health, prompting me to seek counseling for guidance on managing stress and finding balance.

4. Past History (including medical history)
I have not experienced similar problems before.
I have not received treatment or counseling for psychological problems in the past.
I do not have any significant physical illnesses.

5. Academic/occupational functioning level: Despite the success of the business, my personal well-being is affected, leading to decreased job satisfaction.
Interpersonal relationships: My relationships with family members, especially my brothers, have been strained due to my constant focus on work.
Daily life: My workaholic tendencies have led to disrupted sleep patterns and poor self-care habits.

6. Social Support System
I have a close relationship with my brothers, who also work with me, but I find it difficult to share my feelings of being overwhelmed and overworked with them.

2. Presenting Problem
I have been struggling with feelings of guilt and isolation due to my strict low carb diet. I believe that I should not eat out with my friends in order to maintain my weight loss goals, which has led to social withdrawal and loneliness. These feelings started after I overcame urinary cancer at the age of 18 and decided to pursue a career as a male model in Hollywood. The stress of trying to achieve my ideal body image has exacerbated these feelings. I experience guilt and isolation whenever the topic of eating out with friends arises and tend to avoid social gatherings as a result. I have tried to rationalize my thoughts and motivate myself to stick to my diet, but it has only increased my feelings of loneliness.

3. Reason for Seeking Counseling
The persistent feelings of guilt, isolation, and loneliness have impacted my mental well-being and social interactions, prompting me to seek counseling for support.

4. Past History (including medical history)
I have not experienced similar problems before, but overcoming urinary cancer at a young age has had a significant impact on my self-image and relationship with food.
I have not received treatment or counseling for psychological problems in the past.
I do not have any significant physical illnesses apart from my past experience with urinary cancer.

5. Academic/occupational functioning level: N/A
Interpersonal relationships: My social interactions and friendships have been strained due to my self-imposed dietary restrictions and feelings of guilt.
Daily life: My isolation and loneliness have affected my daily routine and social activities.

6. Social Support System
I do not feel comfortable discussing my feelings of guilt and isolation with my friends.

AI_client.intake_form:
Name:
Samuel Anderson
Age:
72
Gender:
male
Occupation: Middle School Art Teacher
Education: Bachelor's Degree in Fine Arts
Marital Status: Single
Family Details: Lives alone, no siblings

2. Presenting Problem
I have a strong desire to write a book before I die, but I constantly feel that I am running out of time due to my age, leading to feelings of despair and pessimism.
These feelings of being unable to achieve my goal started around five years ago when I turned 50.
I believe the cause of these feelings is societal pressure and comparisons with younger successful authors.
The problem has worsened over time, especially as I see younger authors achieving success in writing.
I experience these feelings regularly, especially when I see news about successful authors achieving milestones at a young age.
I have tried setting writing goals and timelines but have not been able to make significant progress in my book.

3. Reason for Seeking Counseling
The realization that my negative thoughts about my age and inability to achieve my goal were affecting my motivation and mental well-being made me seek counseling.

4. Past History (including medical history)
I have not experienced similar problems before.
I have not received treatment or counseling for psychological issues in the past.
I do not have any significant physical illnesses.

5. Academic/occupational functioning level: My job performance has been impacted recently due to my lack of motivation and pessimism.
Interpersonal relationships: My relationships with colleagues have been affected as I often express my doubts about achieving my goal.
Daily life: My motivation levels have impacted my enthusiasm for playing pool and engaging in hobbies.

6. Social Support System
I have a close friend who is supportive, but I have not shared my concerns about my writing goal with them.
AI_client.attitude_instruction: Clients demonstrate a high level of engagement and cooperation with the therapeutic process. They should actively confirm their understanding of the counselor's instructions, ask for clarifications when needed, and willingly provide detailed information about their thoughts, feelings, and behaviors. These clients make reasonable requests for additional support or resources, and they extend the conversation by building on the counselor's suggestions with their own insights or experiences. They reformulate their thoughts in a constructive manner, reflecting on their progress and expressing a hopeful outlook towards the therapeutic outcomes. Overall, their demeanor is open, appreciative, and proactive in seeking improvement.
AI_client.dialogue_history_init:
Counselor: Hello Samuel, it's nice to meet you. How can I help you today?
Client: Hello, it's good to be here. Well, I've been struggling with a deep sense of despair and pessimism because I have always wanted to write a book, but I feel like I'm running out of time because of my age.

I believe that I must have been a bad child since I was in foster care as a child, leading to feelings of self-blame and inadequacy.
These feelings of self-blame started in childhood and have continued to affect me into adulthood.
I think the cause of these feelings stems from being in the foster care system and feeling unwanted.
The problem has progressed, especially after I joined the Navy, where I interact with different individuals.
I experience these feelings of self-blame almost daily, particularly when facing challenges or interactions with others.
I have tried to rationalize these thoughts and distract myself, but they persist.

3. Reason for Seeking Counseling
I decided to seek counseling because these feelings of self-blame are impacting my mental well-being and relationships with others.

4. Past History (including medical history)
I have had similar feelings of self-blame and inadequacy stemming from my time in foster care.
I have not received treatment or counseling for psychological issues before.
I do not have any significant physical illnesses.

5. Academic/occupational functioning level: My job performance in the Navy has been affected due to these feelings of self-blame.
Interpersonal relationships: My interactions with others have been strained as I constantly feel judged and blamed.
Daily life: My feelings of self-blame have affected my ability to focus on tasks and hobbies.

6. Social Support System
I have a few close friends in the Navy that I can talk to, but I find it challenging to discuss these deep-rooted feelings with them.

2. Presenting Problem
I feel a strong sense of pressure to be a better hospital worker because I am also a student. This pressure has been causing stress and feelings of inadequacy.
These feelings started when I began working at the hospital while attending college.
I believe the stress originated from my desire to excel in both my job and studies simultaneously.
Over time, the pressure to perform well has increased, leading to heightened anxiety and self-doubt.
I experience these feelings regularly, especially during busy work and school periods.
I have attempted to manage these feelings by working longer hours and studying more, but it has only increased my stress levels.

3. Reason for Seeking Counseling
The growing stress and feelings of inadequacy have started to impact my mental health and overall well-being, which prompted me to seek counseling.

4. Past History (including medical history)
I have not encountered similar problems before.
I have not undergone treatment or counseling for psychological issues previously.
There are no significant physical illnesses in my medical history.

5. Academic/occupational functioning level
Occupational functioning level: I have noticed a decline in my performance at work due to increased stress and self-doubt.
Interpersonal relationships: My relationships with coworkers have been strained due to my elevated anxiety levels.
Daily life: The stress and pressure have affected my ability to focus on my studies and disrupted my sleep patterns.

6. Social Support System
While I have some friends I can talk to, I have not felt comfortable sharing my work and study-related stress with them.

2. Presenting Problem
The main issue I want to discuss is my constant fear of being overweight and feeling like I will never achieve my weight loss goals. This fear started when I cheated on my diet, causing me to spiral into thoughts of being overweight forever. The stress level was high when I cheated on my diet, and I feel like the cause is my perfectionistic tendencies.
The problem has been progressing as I find myself constantly preoccupied with thoughts of being overweight, which is affecting my diet adherence and self-esteem. I often experience these fears after indulging in any food outside my diet plan and tend to overthink the consequences.
I have tried different types of diets and exercise routines to achieve my weight loss goals, but the fear of being overweight persists.

3. Reason for Seeking Counseling
I decided to seek counseling this time as the fear of being overweight is significantly impacting my mental health and motivation to continue with my weight loss journey.

4. Past History (including medical history)
I have faced similar challenges with my weight loss journey in the past, particularly when I deviate from my diet plan. In those instances, I would overcompensate by restricting my food intake excessively.
I have not received treatment or counseling for psychological problems previously.
I do not have any significant physical illnesses.

5. Academic/occupational functioning level: Seeking to go to school to become a veterinarian, but the fear of being overweight is affecting my focus and motivation.
Interpersonal relationships: My relationships with family are strained due to my preoccupation with weight and dieting.
Daily life: My fear of being overweight has impacted my eating habits and frequency of going to the gym for workouts.

6. Social Support System
I have a supportive group of friends who I can talk to, but they may not fully understand the intensity of my fears and struggles with weight and dieting.

2. Presenting Problem
I believe that I may have low self-esteem, leading me to resort to fad diets to maintain my physical appearance for my modeling career.
This issue with low self-esteem and reliance on fad diets started after overcoming urinary cancer at age 18.
The stress level when these problems first occurred was high, as I felt the need to make drastic changes to my appearance post-recovery.
Over time, the problem has progressed as I constantly judge my self-worth based on my physical appearance and struggle with body image issues.
Currently, I find myself following restrictive diets and feeling critical of myself when I don't meet certain physical standards.
I have attempted various fad diets and intense workout regimens to address this issue, but they have not brought lasting satisfaction.

3. Reason for Seeking Counseling
The decisive factor that made me seek counseling this time was realizing the negative impact of my low self-esteem and unhealthy diet habits on my mental and physical well-being.

4. Past History (including medical history)
I have not experienced similar problems before.
I have not received treatment or counseling for psychological problems in the past.
I have a history of overcoming urinary cancer at a young age.
I do not have any significant physical illnesses apart from the past cancer experience.

5. Academic/occupational functioning level: Aspiring male model in Hollywood
Interpersonal relationships: Not specified
Daily life: Focused on maintaining physical appearance through diet and exercise routines.

6. Social Support System
I have some friends and acquaintances in the modeling industry whom I can talk to, but I have not discussed my self-esteem and diet concerns with them.

I do not have any significant physical illnesses.

6. Social Support System

2. Presenting Problem
I have been experiencing feelings of self-doubt and pessimism after winning a marathon. These feelings started immediately after winning the marathon a month ago. I believe the cause of these feelings is the pressure to replicate or exceed my previous success. The problem has progressively worsened since winning the marathon, especially as I am constantly thinking about the possibility of not winning again. I experience these feelings daily, particularly when I think about upcoming races or training sessions. So far, I have tried to combat these thoughts with positive thinking and visualization techniques, but they have not been effective.

3. Reason for Seeking Counseling
The persistent negative thoughts and self-doubt have started to impact my motivation to train and participate in races, which led me to seek counseling to address these issues.

4. Past History (including medical history)
I have not experienced similar issues before.
I have not received any treatment or counseling for psychological problems in the past.
I do not have any significant physical illnesses.

5. Academic/occupational functioning level: My athletic performance and training routines have been impacted by these negative thoughts.
Interpersonal relationships: My relationships with fellow athletes and coaches have been strained due to my lack of motivation and negative outlook.
Daily life: My eating habits and sleep schedule have been affected by the constant pressure I feel.

6. Social Support System
I have a few friends in the athletic community who I can talk to, but I have not discussed these specific issues with them.

2. Presenting Problem
I often struggle with perfectionism, especially when creating music playlists. The problem started a few months ago when I couldn't find one more song to add to my playlist, leading me to believe the entire playlist is ruined.
I experience intense stress and frustration when faced with this situation, which has caused me to avoid creating playlists altogether.
The problem has progressed to the point where I now have difficulty enjoying music in general due to the fear of creating a "ruined" playlist.
I typically experience these feelings in the evening when I try to work on my playlists.
I have tried to overcome this issue by seeking out new music and distractions, but it has not been effective in resolving the problem.

3. Reason for Seeking Counseling
I realized that my perfectionism is hindering my passion for music production and affecting my overall well-being, prompting me to seek counseling.

4. Past History (including medical history)
I have not experienced similar problems before.
I have not received treatment or counseling for psychological problems in the past.
I do not have any significant physical illnesses.

5. Academic/occupational functioning level: My music production has been affected by my perfectionism, leading to a decrease in creativity and productivity.
Interpersonal relationships: My relationships have been strained due to my avoidance of social activities related to music.
Daily life: My sleep patterns have been disrupted as I often stay up late trying to perfect my playlists.

6. Social Support System
I have a few friends I can talk to, but they do not understand the intensity of my struggle with perfectionism in music production.

2. Presenting Problem

The stress level was moderate when the problem first occurred, triggered by comparisons with quarterbacks who have more experience.
The problem has progressed as I constantly filter out my positive achievements and solely focus on my perceived shortcomings.
I experience these feelings regularly, especially after games or practices where I compare my performance to others.
I have tried to boost my confidence through positive self-talk but have not been able to overcome these feelings on my own.

I have not experienced similar problems before in my career.
I have not received treatment or counseling for psychological issues previously.
No significant physical illnesses are reported.

5. Academic/occupational functioning level: My job performance has been impacted due to self-doubt affecting my gameplay.
Interpersonal relationships: The pressure I put on myself has affected my relationships with teammates and coaches.
Daily life: The stress and self-doubt have caused disruptions in my sleep and eating routines.

6. Social Support System
I have teammates and coaching staff who I can talk to about football-related issues but find it hard to discuss my self-doubt with them.

I experience these feelings primarily in social settings or when meeting new people.
I have tried to change the conversation topic or deflect from my profession, but it only temporarily alleviates the anxiety.

3. Reason for Seeking Counseling
I decided to seek counseling as these feelings of insecurity have started to impact my social life and overall well-being.

4. Past History (including medical history)
I have not experienced similar problems before related to feeling insecure about my profession.
I have not received treatment or counseling for psychological problems in the past.
I do not have any significant physical illnesses.

5. Academic/occupational functioning level: My job performance as an accountant has not been affected by these feelings of insecurity.
Interpersonal relationships: I struggle to form new connections due to my avoidance of discussions about my profession.
Daily life: My social anxiety has affected my ability to enjoy social activities, impacting my overall quality of life.

6. Social Support System
I have a close friend who is supportive, but they might not fully understand the depth of my social anxiety related to my profession.

Name:
Whitney Lawson
Age:
27
Gender:
female
Occupation: Aspiring Fashion Designer
Education: Studying at a prestigious designing school in New York
Marital Status: Single
Family Details: Lives independently in New York

2. Presenting Problem
I am experiencing extreme anxiety and fear about my financial situation and future as a fashion designer.
These feelings started when I moved to New York to study at a prestigious designing school.
The stress level was high when I realized the financial burden of school fees and living expenses in a big city.
The problem has worsened as time has passed, especially when I struggle to make ends meet.
I constantly worry about not being able to afford school fees and fear ending up on the streets before I graduate.
These feelings of impending doom occur almost daily, especially when I receive bills or think about the future.
I have tried budgeting and financial planning, but the anxiety persists.

3. Reason for Seeking Counseling
The overwhelming anxiety about my financial situation and future career prospects has significantly impacted my mental well-being and ability to focus on my studies, leading me to seek counseling for support.

4. Past History (including medical history)
I have not experienced similar financial anxieties before.
I have not received treatment or counseling for psychological problems in the past.
I do not have any significant physical illnesses.

5. Academic/occupational functioning level: My academic performance has started to decline due to the constant anxiety and fear.
Interpersonal relationships: My relationships with classmates and friends have been strained due to my stress and worry about finances.
Daily life: The anxiety has affected my sleep and eating patterns, making it hard to focus on my studies.

6. Social Support System
I have a few friends and classmates I can talk to, but I find it challenging to discuss my financial fears and anxieties with them.

2. Presenting Problem
I have been experiencing self-doubt and feelings of inadequacy regarding my skills in computer building. These feelings started when I recently built a few computers and considered selling them.
The stress level increased when I thought about selling the computers, fearing they would not be good enough for my community.
These feelings have progressed over time, especially after receiving positive feedback from friends on my computer building skills. I constantly underestimate my abilities and worry about others' perceptions.
I experience these feelings whenever I plan to showcase my skills or receive feedback on my work.
I have tried seeking reassurance from friends and researching online for validation, but it hasn't helped alleviate my self-doubts.

3. Reason for Seeking Counseling
The increasing self-doubt and feelings of inadequacy have been impacting my motivation to pursue my interests and potential opportunities, leading me to seek counseling for guidance and support.

4. Past History (including medical history)
I have not experienced similar problems before.
I have not received treatment or counseling for psychological problems in the past.
I do not have any significant physical illnesses.

5. Academic/occupational functioning level: My job performance as a mechanic has not been affected, but my interest in pursuing computer building projects has waned.
Interpersonal relationships: My relationships with friends have been strained due to my constant seeking of reassurance and validation.
Daily life: My self-doubt has affected my motivation to engage in hobbies like building computers.

6. Social Support System
I have a few friends I can talk to, but I struggle to open up about my feelings of self-doubt and inadequacy.

Overall, their demeanor is open, appreciative, and proactive in seeking improvement.

6. Social Support System

2. Presenting Problem
I feel like a failure because my girlfriend did not enjoy the dessert I made for a three-course dinner I cooked for her.
These feelings of failure started after the dinner incident with my girlfriend.
The stress level was high during the dinner as I wanted everything to be perfect for her.
The problem has progressed, and I now find myself doubting my cooking skills and feeling inadequate.
I experience these feelings whenever I cook for others or receive feedback on my dishes.
I have tried to rationalize and brush off the incident but find it difficult to shake off the feelings of failure.

3. Reason for Seeking Counseling
The incident with my girlfriend made me realize that these feelings of failure are affecting my confidence in my cooking skills and overall well-being, leading me to seek counseling.

4. Past History (including medical history)
I have not experienced similar problems before.
I have not received treatment or counseling for psychological problems in the past.
I do not have any significant physical illnesses.

5. Academic/occupational functioning level: My cooking performance has been impacted due to my feelings of failure.
Interpersonal relationships: My relationship with my girlfriend has been strained due to my reactions to feedback.
Daily life: My self-esteem has been affected by this incident, influencing my motivation to cook and engage in activities I once enjoyed.

6. Social Support System
I have a small group of friends I can talk to, but I find it hard to open up about my feelings of failure with them.

I realized that this fear of rejection was holding me back from forming meaningful relationships and affecting my overall happiness, leading me to seek counseling.

I have experienced similar fear of rejection in past dating experiences, leading to avoidance of potential romantic relationships.
I have not received treatment or counseling for psychological problems before.
I do not have any significant physical illnesses.

5. Academic/occupational functioning level: My job performance has not been significantly affected by this fear.
Interpersonal relationships: My fear of rejection has hindered my ability to form romantic relationships and deep connections with others.
Daily life: My fear of rejection has caused anxiety and stress in social situations.

6. Social Support System
I have a supportive family and a close friend I can talk to about personal issues, but I have not shared my fear of rejection with them.

2. Presenting Problem
I feel like a useless teacher when my student fails his English literature exam, resulting in feelings of incompetence and self-blame.

I believe the stress level increased when multiple students started struggling in my classes.
The problem has progressed to the point where I constantly personalize students' academic performance, leading to a sense of failure.
I experience these feelings after every exam period, and they tend to worsen during grading season.
I have tried seeking feedback from colleagues and implementing new teaching strategies, but the feelings persist.

3. Reason for Seeking Counseling
I realized that these feelings of incompetence were affecting both my mental well-being and teaching effectiveness, prompting me to seek counseling.

4. Past History (including medical history)
I have not experienced similar problems before.
I have not sought treatment or counseling for psychological issues in the past.
I do not have any significant physical illnesses.

5. Academic/occupational functioning level: My self-perceived failure has affected my confidence in teaching and may be influencing my students' performance.
Interpersonal relationships: My relationships with students have been affected by my self-blame and feeling of incompetence.
Daily life: My stress levels have impacted my sleep and eating habits.

6. Social Support System
I have a supportive sister who I can confide in, but I feel hesitant to discuss my feelings of incompetence with her.

2. Presenting Problem
I struggle with labeling myself negatively when I make mistakes, which affects my self-confidence and performance in activities like playing softball.
This issue started during my teenage years but has become more prominent in the past few months.
I believe the stress of work deadlines may have triggered this negative self-labeling.
Over time, this problem has led me to avoid participating in activities I enjoy, fearing I will underperform and be judged by others.
I experience these negative self-labeling thoughts every time I make a mistake or face a performance challenge.
I have tried to challenge these thoughts with positive affirmations but find it difficult to overcome them.

3. Reason for Seeking Counseling
I decided to seek counseling when I noticed that this pattern of negative self-labeling was impacting my enjoyment of activities and my self-esteem.

4. Past History (including medical history)
I have not experienced similar problems before.
I have not received treatment or counseling for psychological issues in the past.
I do not have any significant physical illnesses.

5. Academic/occupational functioning level: My job performance has not been significantly affected, but my participation in recreational activities has decreased.
Interpersonal relationships: I find it hard to connect with others due to my fear of being judged for my perceived failures.
Daily life: My self-confidence issues have impacted my self-care routines and sleep patterns.

6. Social Support System
I have a few friends who I can talk to, but I haven't discussed my self-confidence issues with them.

I decided to seek counseling because these feelings of self-doubt are hindering my ability to enjoy cooking and pursue my culinary dreams.

I have not experienced similar problems before.

I do not have any significant physical illnesses.

Daily life: My self-esteem issues have affected my sleep patterns and overall well-being.
